answers.answer: I'm sure that after two months with no meds, you must not be feeling well at all.  You cannot continue this.  You will just feel worse and worse.  I'd suggest contacting the manufacturer of your meds.  They often have programs to help "if you can't afford your medication". Also, relatively speaking, thyroid meds are pretty inexpensive.  Another trick to make them even cheaper is to ask your doctor to prescribe double your dose and take half each day.  The double dose usually is not much more expensive than the single, and it goes twice as long (of course, you can't do this if you take any meds with T3 in them).If there's any way you can possibly swing it, you really should have FT3, FT4 and TSH tested after two months off meds to see where you are.Since you have no thyroid, meds are not optional.  You have to find a way to continue meds as this is probably the most important thing in your life right now.  Any other corner you can cut on expenses is preferable.No OTC meds sold in the U.S. can contain thyroid hormones, so there is nothing to replace prescription meds.  Anything you might find that purports to would probably be as expensive as your prescription.
